bestBHT.bht: In his letter to the early Christians, Peter advises them to avoid suffering as wrongdoers, which includes refraining from acts like murder or theft that are punishable by law. Additionally, he cautions against meddling in the affairs of others, acting as self-appointed overseers who excessively involve themselves in the lives of their Gentile neighbors. Rather than trying to forcefully conform others to their own standards, believers should focus on their own conduct, avoiding any actions that would bring reproach upon the name of Christ.

Henry Alford: Let no one of you suffer as a murderer or malefactor, as opposed to a well-doer."
Let no one of you suffer as a prier into other men's matters.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Reproached in the name of Christ" I say ( :-), "FOR let none," c.
Christians, from mistaken zeal, under the plea of faithfulness, might readily step out of their own calling and make themselves judges of the acts of unbelievers.
Literally, "a bishop in what is (not his own, but) another's" province...a self-constituted bishop in others' concerns.
Albert Barnes: But let none of you suffer as a murderer."
If you must be called to suffer, see that it be not for crime.
One who busies himself with what does not concern him; that is, one who pries into the affairs of another.
Marvin Vincent: One who usurps authority in matters not within his province.
The officious interference of Christians in the affairs of their Gentile neighbors.
Excess of zeal to conform them to the Christian standard.
John Calvin: It behoved Christians to deserve well of all, even when they were badly and cruelly treated by the world."
He would not have God’s children to be in the same condition, so as to draw on themselves by a wicked life the punishment allotted by the laws.
The sin here referred to must have some public act, punishable by law. The word means an observer of other people’s affairs, but he must have done so for some sinister purpose.
Philip Schaff: It is of reproach in the name of Christ, and of that only, that I speak; for let no one suppose that he can suffer with just cause as an evil-doer, and yet have the blessedness that I affirm.
The fourth form of evil is marked off, by the repetition of the 'as,' from the former three as of a different kind and gravity.

The term points, therefore, to an offence, which came as close to the peculiar temptations of Christians... It is that of officious interference in the affairs of their Gentile neighbours, in excess of zeal to conform them to the Christian standard.
Archibald T. Robertson: Let no one of you suffer...two specific crimes (murderer, thief) and one general phrase...and one unusual term αλλοτριεπισχοπος (a meddler in other men's matters)."
The word was apparently coined by Peter...from αλλοτριος (belonging to another) and επισκοπος, overseer, inspector. The idea is apparently one who spies out the affairs of other men.
It is interesting to note...that επισκοπος here is the word for 'bishop' and so suggests also preachers meddling in the work of other preachers.
John Gill: But let none of you suffer as a murderer...."
or as a thief; whose fine or mulct, according to the Jewish law, was a fivefold or fourfold restitution...."
or as a busybody in other men's matters; 'or as a bishop in another man's diocese'; that concerns himself in things he has nothing to do with....
John Wesley: Let none of you deservedly suffer, as an evildoer - In any kind.

It is crucial that they do not engage in acts such as murder or theft, which are clearly forbidden and punishable by law. However, Peter also warns against becoming meddlers in the affairs of others, essentially behaving like self-appointed overseers or preachers who excessively involve themselves in the lives and decisions of their Gentile neighbors. Rather than being overzealous in trying to conform others to their own Christian standards, believers are urged to focus on their own conduct and avoid any sins that would bring reproach upon the name of Christ.
